intro: Euaraliopsis, commonly known as the "false arum," is a genus of flowering plants in the family Araliaceae. It consists of a single species, Euaraliopsis tenuifolia, which is native to the tropical regions of South America. The plant is characterized by its distinctive, arrow-shaped leaves and small, clustered flowers that are often surrounded by modified leaves called bracts. It typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and stream banks. Due to its unique morphology and limited distribution, Euaraliopsis is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
